GeneralInfo.InterchangeaStrategies: No information about interchangable strategies. It is stressed that Spanish clothes uses Strategy 1, Spanish kinship 4
GeneralInfo.RelStrategies: Prononouns are used to express nominal possession. Pronominal strategies correspond to nominal strartegies, except for juxtaposition

Semantics.Possessed:
non-obligatorily possessed: glasses, etc. Kinship terms which are borrowed from Spanish use another strategy to mark possession - with possessive pronoun (nowadays they are in use much more than the original Baure words)
body parts: head, brain, eye, tongue, tooth, skin, face, back, hand palm, plant parts: leaf, stem, branch, tree, kinship, clothes (although borrowed from Spanish), 'field', 'feather', 'horn' Danielsen2007

Pronoun.Asymmetry: 3rd person pronouns are demonstratives. There is destinction for gender . Oblique form is different rom the absolute in demonstratives and in 1st person singular. There is no difference in 1st person plural or in the 2nd person

Semantics.Possessed: nouns that refer to parts of a body, such as internal organs if they are possessed alienably vonPrince2012: 129 Pre-nominal possessive pronouns can be used with all nouns, including transitive and inflected nouns.

Pronoun.Remark: I don't know if the pronoun or the is the bound moroheme. Probably is bound, because it is also the prefix on linkers

Morpheme.Label: classifier
Morpheme.Remark: Pre-nominal possessive pronouns and the two linkers are always prefixed by one of three nominal classifiers. They differ from typical possessive s in Oceanic languages in that they are not relational s, but rather agree with the lexical gender of the head noun: In contrast to other Oceanic languages [compare e.g. Lichtenberk, 1983, 2009b], the choice of is independent of the possessor’s intentions with regard to the possessum.
Morpheme.Explanation: Pre-nominal possessive pronouns and the two linkers are always prefixed by one of three nominal classifiers

Adnominal.Translation: his/her bone (the bone is not a physical part of its possessor)

Predicative.Remarks: linkers and pre-nominal possessive pronouns can also be used as predicates without the presence of a possessed noun

?are there semantic restrictions?
nouns that refer to parts of a body, such as internal organs if they are possessed alienably vonPrince2012: 129

Morpheme.Label: linker
Morpheme.Explanation: -e (singular)/ -an (plural)

Morpheme.Label: classifier/linker
Morpheme.Remark: Pre-nominal possessive pronouns and the two linkers are always prefixed by one of three nominal classifiers. The three s are s-, m- and the zero morpheme ∅-. They differ from typical possessive s in Oceanic languages in that they are not relational s, but rather agree with the lexical gender of the head noun: In contrast to other Oceanic languages [compare e.g. Lichtenberk, 1983, 2009b], the choice of is independent of the possessor’s intentions with regard to the possessum. In some cases, the choice of depends on whether a noun fits into a certain semantic domain. For example, when talking about the possession of animals, everyone will use inevitably the same (∅-), independent of whether they intend to eat, breed, sell or play with the animal.
Morpheme.Explanation: Pre-nominal possessive pronouns and the two linkers are always prefixed by one of three nominal classifiers.

Adnominal.Translation: Baeluk's bone (a bone from an animal which is in the possession of Baeluk)

GeneralInfo.InterchangeaStrategies: For the most nouns the form with -j- (alienable) is also possible. For example, in case of modification it is possible to use alienable strategy for inalienable possession "my wooden leg"

Semantics.Possessed: Rogava1966 describe it as "body parts" and part-whole. They also mention "soul", "name". Gorbunova2009 gives a more detailed description - body parts: leg, hand, back, face // blod, skin// some organs//some kinship: brother, son, sister, daughter (father and mother have a special prefix "ja")// parts of inanimate objects if the word is the same as (or derived from) body part. Gorbunova2009:151 mentions that "inalienable nouns are obligatorily possessed", but she does not give an exhaustive list and it is not clear if those nouns are a subset or all nouns which can participate in inalienable possession. Some nouns appear as alienable as well as inalienable: moustache Rogava1966; Gorbunova2009

Pronoun.Remark: Complexity is not clear! Gorbunova 2009 analyses the marker as alternation: "sǝ-/s-" (one morpheme). RogavaKershava analyse it as two morphemes: person-number marker "s" and the marker of inalienable possession "ǝ".

Adnominal.Translation: I am making my head hurt (I am breaking my head)

Semantics.Possessor: more variation with 1st, 2nd person. Gorbunova2009 mentions that even some body parts can get marked alienably Gorbunova2009
Semantics.Possessed: some organs: muscles, some kinship (the new borrowed words for 'son' and 'daughter' also use alienable marking), 'wife', 'husband', parts of inanimate objects. If possessed has a modifier only alienable possession is used. Depending on the syntactic position, alienable possession can be used even for inalienable nouns, Gorbunova2009 mentions the whole possessive DP in a predicative position: "you my-Allienable brother" Gorbunova2009

GeneralInfo.WordOrder: VSO and VOS (‘theme signs’ is used when the proximate acts on the obviative)
GeneralInfo.NominalPhrase: all nouns are either grammatically ‘animate’ or grammatically ‘inanimate’. verbs and demonstratives inflect for animate and inanimate nouns differently. (Demonstrative precedes the noun). Distinction in the nominal structure is between so-called ‘proximate’ and ‘obviative’ nouns. The proximate noun is left unmarked ((15a)), while an obviative referent is marked with the suffix -a. No determiners, no definitness markers
GeneralInfo.InterchangeaStrategies: distribution of -im is unclear (see Wolfart 1973 for discussion). Mühlbauer argues that different semantic classes can be distinguished on the bases of detransitivisation strategies: turnng a relational noun into a sortal

Semantics.Possessed: it is not clear which obligatorily possessed (dependednt) nouns really are in this class. Obligatorily possessed `hand' , `jaw', 'head', `mother' are in this class, but also `shue'

'father', `grandchildren', `yongest brother', are obligatorily possessed (dependednt) nouns in this class. Also `canoe', `jacket', `house', `bone tool for scrapping fat' seem to be obligstorily possessed. all dependent nouns that use the impersonal verbal strategy denote kinship or close relations. But also `dog', `cat' are in this class.

Morpheme.Explanation: distribution is unclear (see Wolfart 1973 for discussion).Junker (2003) has analyzed this morpheme as marking disjoint reference, in parallel to a homophonous morpheme found on verbs that marks obviative objects

distribution is unclear (see Wolfart 1973 for discussion).Junker (2003) has analyzed this morpheme as marking disjoint reference, in parallel to a homophonous morpheme found on verbs that marks obviative objects

GeneralInfo.WordOrder: verb-initial with a preference for VSO order.
GeneralInfo.CaseSystem: In Guajiro the subject and object roles remain unmarked. There is a set of relational stems that function as oblique case markers.
GeneralInfo.NominalPhrase: nouns marked for definiteness. prenominal definite articles: ti (feminine), či (masculine) and na (plural). Adjectives and the possessor in a genitive construction follow the noun they modify. Demonstratives, personal pronouns (third person only), nouns marked for definiteness, verbal subject prefixes and possessive prefixes (third person only), the (suffixed) object of a transitive verb in a non-present tense, and the (suffixed) subject of a non-transitive verb must be specified for gender–number.
GeneralInfo.RelStrategies: I have not found examples for Nominal possesison of alienable nouns, but most probably it is parallel to pronominal possesion of alienable nouns and requires a relational suffix

cloth

Morpheme.Explanation: The suffix forms "the relational form of the noun"

GeneralInfo.WordOrder: Word order in Toba is relatively free. In transitive clauses, SVO predominates, and in intransitive clauses VS. Possessors tend to follow possessed elements.

Semantics.Possessed: body parts (including the outer parts, internal organs, fluids and secretions, as well as some features and attributes of the body), kin terms, p arasites that live in man, diseases, images of the body (like shadow) "physical, mental and spiritual bodies intimately related to human beings" (name, dream), intrinsic human properties (like names) and some objects made by humans (ornaments, clothing, housing, utensils, musical instruments, vehicles, weapons and tools)
The names that belong to this field refers to items that can be separated from their owners ("hat", "shovel") or are commonly not ownable ("wood", "earth"), as shown in the following examples:

Pronoun.Remark: Awa Pit has distinct pronoun inventories for subject, object/beneficiary and possessor. Awa Pit pronouns (based on Curnow 1997: 86, 94)
Pronoun.Asymmetry: A plural possessor is either indicated by means of the corresponding singular form, or by the plural nominative. Nominative 1sg "na" 1pl "au"

Morpheme.Explanation: The genitive case marker of Awa Pit coincides with conservative Quechua dialects in two of its allomorphs (-pa, -p)

GeneralInfo.RelStrategies: Correspondence: the genitive marker on the pronoun is the same as the genitive marker on a nominal possessor.

Morpheme.Label: genitive case
Morpheme.Explanation: The genitive case marker occurs on the dependent (possessor) member of a possessive construction JOSE CAMACHO, LILIANA PAREDES and LILIANA SÄNCHEZ: The genitive clitic and the genitive construction in Andean Spanish

GeneralInfo.CaseSystem: Maasai nouns are morphologically for Case. The two Case forms---the form of subjects of transitive verbs Nominative and the form of direct objects of transitive verbs Accusative---are marked through tonal morphology
GeneralInfo.NominalPhrase: gender prefix on nouns appear in complementary distribution with demonstratives. (But these morphemes appear on predicate nominals too, which seems to indicate that their presence does not entail a full DP structure. Furthermore, these morphemes do not specify the definiteness value of the DP on which they appear) modifiers follow the noun

Morpheme.Label: possessed agreement
Morpheme.Explanation: agreement in gender with the possessum: ɛ̀-feminine, lɛ̀ masculine

Morpheme.Label: possessor agreement
Morpheme.Explanation: agreement in number with the possessor, èn singular possessor, ̀n plural possessor

GeneralInfo.CaseSystem: nominal arguments are marked as either proximate or obviative
GeneralInfo.NominalPhrase: all nouns are either grammatically ‘animate’ or grammatically ‘inanimate’. verbs and demonstratives inflect for animate and inanimate nouns differently.
GeneralInfo.InterchangeaStrategies: hair, if it is clipped, takes alienable marking

Semantics.Possessed: mother, daughter, husband, hair, horse, ring
brother in law, pipes, hair (when clipped), rabbit, cow, bracelet

Adnominal.Translation: This is my (clipping of his) hair

GeneralInfo.NominalPhrase: definite articles (they are absent in construct state and noun inflection)
GeneralInfo.InterchangeaStrategies: The same noun can be marked differently ('woman') emphasis of focus on the possessed triggers the PP (Stolz:71), the presence of a modifier, such as numeral also triggers PP (blocks suffixation) (Stolz: 84)
GeneralInfo.RelStrategies: posessive suffixation does not correspond one-to-one to the nominal construct state, construct state is a subset. A large number of nouns can take suffixes. A much more limited set of nouns end up in construct state

Semantics.Possessed:
All obligatorily possesed nouns are a subset of this class. invoke the notion of inalienability. Stolz classifies them as: body parts, kinship, life-cycle, home, abstract properties, part-whole (half, share), clothes/belongings, various (street, money). Examples: brother, mouth, hand, eye, neck, head, childhood, country, master, thing, life, name, wife, husband, children, self, place, money, need, beauty, room, pocket, etc...
Ambros 1998:75 Stolz

Morpheme.Remark: Inflected nouns don't combine with definite articles
Morpheme.Explanation: characterises noun as possessed! NB: it does not appear with all stams. Stems ending with a vowel don't seem to need it

Semantics.Possessed: harbor, field, affair, family, religion, warehouse, studies, oven, bread, work Stolz

Morpheme.Explanation: inflected preposition, stem allomorhy, depending which pronoun the preposition combines with

Semantics.Possessed: father, mother, duaghter (close blood relation),

Juxtaposition.Remark: the head noun lacks overt determination, Construct State

Semantics.Possessed: husband, wife, maid, author, widow,
Semantics.RelationPRPD: mixed: a broader range of possessive relations. also contextually specified relations.

Morpheme.Explanation: possessive marker

Adnominal.Translation: Peter's car (definite)/ a car of Peter's(indefinite)
